misconceptions.name: Grade is hard-coded instead of read from user
misconceptions.description: The program assigns a fixed numeric grade (95.0) in code rather than reading a grade value from the keyboard as required by the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that it is acceptable to test the grade logic with a hard-coded grade value instead of actually reading the grade from the user for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this assignment, the program must prompt the user and read the numeric grade from the keyboard (e.g., using Scanner.nextInt() or nextDouble()) and then base the letter grade computation on that input value.
symptoms: Program never prompts the user for a grade value
The variable grade is always 95.0 regardless of any user input
User cannot influence the letter grade output
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely focusing on practicing conditional logic in isolation and not integrating the required input step for this specific problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded initialization of grade with a Scanner read. For example: prompt with "Enter grade: " and then do double grade = input_scanner.nextDouble(); before running the if/else logic.
related_concepts: Separating test code from final solution
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The grade variable is explicitly set to 95.0 and no code ever reads a grade from input; the comment says this block is independent practice, indicating they did not implement the specified input behavior here.

evidence.note: The student hard-codes grade = 95.0 and explicitly treats this as separate practice logic, rather than reading the grade from the user as required.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Using separate if statements with overlapping ranges for letter grades
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple independent if statements that only test lower bounds (>=) for each letter grade instead of a mutually exclusive if-else-if chain or correctly bounded ranges. This causes multiple letter grades to be printed for a single numeric grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that checking the grade thresholds in descending order with separate if statements is enough to ensure only the correct single letter grade is printed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Each if statement is evaluated independently; if multiple conditions are true, all corresponding bodies will execute. For mutually exclusive grade ranges, you must either use an if-else-if chain or explicit upper and lower bounds so exactly one condition matches (or use an else for the remaining case).
symptoms: For grade = 95.0, output would be A, B, C, and D each on its own line.
For grade = 85.0, output would be B, C, and D instead of a single B.
For any grade >= 90, all A–D conditions are true.
No single default/else branch for F; it is only printed when grade < 60.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding how multiple if statements execute and how to represent non-overlapping numeric ranges with conditionals.
related_concepts: Short-circuiting and control flow in conditionals
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The grade checks use only lower bounds with five independent if statements; this pattern deterministically leads to overlapping conditions and multiple outputs for a single grade.

evidence.note: Five independent if statements check only lower bounds. For grade = 95.0, all first four conditions are true, so A, B, C, and D would all be printed.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Independent IF Statements for Mutually Exclusive Ranges
misconceptions.description: The student uses a series of independent `if` statements where mutually exclusive logic (only printing one grade) is required. This results in grades satisfying multiple conditions (e.g., 95 satisfies >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60), causing multiple letter grades to be printed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that writing five independent `if` statements in descending order of grade boundaries is sufficient to correctly select only one grade letter.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To define mutually exclusive ranges and ensure only one branch is executed, the student must use the `if-else if-else` structure.
symptoms: Multiple letter grades are printed for any input grade >= 60.
The control flow does not stop after the correct range is found.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the semantic difference between sequential independent `if` blocks and a conditional `if-else if` chain.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the conditional structure using `else if` statements to link the requirements together. For example, `if (grade >= 90)` followed by `else if (grade >= 80)`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure of five independent `if` statements is unambiguous and directly causes the erroneous output for calculating grades.

evidence.note: A series of independent 'if' statements instead of an 'if-else if' chain, leading to non-exclusive execution paths.

misconceptions.name: Failure to Read Input Dynamically
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded a test value for the grade instead of using the existing `Scanner` to read the numeric grade from the user, as required by the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have treated the assignment as only a logic puzzle, hardcoding the variable `grade` for testing without fulfilling the input requirement of the prompt.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must include a prompt and use `input_scanner.nextDouble()` to read the grade from the keyboard dynamically.
symptoms: The value of 'grade' is fixed (95.0), making the program non-interactive for the grading calculation part.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation against the problem requirements, possibly focusing solely on the conditional logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded initialization of `grade` with code that prompts the user and reads the input using the `Scanner` object defined earlier.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly assigns a static value (95.0) to `grade` instead of using the `Scanner` available in the code.

evidence.note: The grade is assigned a static value (95.0) rather than being read from user input, failing the I/O requirement.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded input instead of reading from user
misconceptions.description: Student uses a hardcoded grade value (95.0) instead of reading the grade from user input via Scanner. The Scanner object is created but never used to read the grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that for practice purposes, hardcoding a test value is acceptable, or did not complete implementing the full requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read the numeric grade from user input using Scanner.nextDouble() after prompting the user with 'Enter grade: '
symptoms: Grade value is hardcoded as 95.0
No user prompt for grade input
Scanner is created but never used for grade input
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation - student treated grade logic as isolated practice code rather than completing the full Q3 requirement
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a prompt: System.out.print("Enter grade: "); followed by: double grade = input_scanner.nextDouble();
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows grade = 95.0 as hardcoded, and the student's comment states the grade logic is 'completely independent' practice code, making this unmistakably an incomplete implementation.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95.0 instead of being read from user input via Scanner

// below is some grade checking logic that I am practicing

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Independent if statements instead of if-else-if chain
misconceptions.description: Student uses independent if statements (not if-else-if) to check mutually exclusive grade ranges. This causes multiple conditions to evaluate to true and print multiple letter grades for a single numeric input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that using multiple independent if statements with >= comparisons will correctly identify and print a single letter grade, not understanding that all true conditions will execute.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For mutually exclusive conditions (where only one can be true), use if-else-if-else chains so that once a condition is true and executed, remaining conditions are skipped. Alternatively, use upper bounds: if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100), etc.
symptoms: Grade 95 produces output: A, B, C, D (four lines instead of one)
All conditions where grade >= threshold print their output
Multiple letter grades appear for a single input
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how independent if statements work - student does not realize that each if is evaluated independently regardless of previous outcomes
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change to if-else-if structure: if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ... else if (grade >= 70) ... This ensures only the first true branch executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the pattern is clear and direct: five independent if statements checking overlapping ranges will cause multiple outputs for grade 95. This is a fundamental control flow error.

evidence.note: Five independent if statements with overlapping conditions. For grade=95, all first four conditions are true, so A, B, C, D all print.

misconceptions.name: Hard-coding the grade instead of reading user input
misconceptions.description: The program never reads a numeric grade from the user for the grade calculator task. Instead, it assigns a fixed value (95.0) to the grade variable, so the grade logic always runs on that single value rather than on user-entered data.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that it's acceptable to practice the grade logic using a hard-coded grade value instead of actually reading the grade from the keyboard as required by the problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must prompt the user (e.g., "Enter grade: ") and read the numeric grade from the keyboard using Scanner (e.g., nextInt or nextDouble). The computed letter grade must be based on that user input, not a fixed constant in the code.
symptoms: No prompt like "Enter grade:" appears before computing the letter grade.
No Scanner call (nextInt/nextDouble) is used to read the grade.
The grade variable is always 95.0, so the output cannot change based on user input.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student reused a distance-calculation example that already had Scanner use and then added grading logic as a separate practice block, focusing on conditionals and not on matching the assignment's input specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded grade value with a prompt and a Scanner read, e.g., print "Enter grade: " and then use input_scanner.nextInt() or nextDouble() to store the user's grade in the grade variable.
related_concepts: Separation of test values from program logic
Using variables to store user input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the only grade value is a literal 95.0 and there is no Scanner call or prompt associated with grade input, despite the assignment explicitly requiring reading a grade.

evidence.note: The grade is assigned a fixed literal value (95.0) and there is no Scanner input or prompt for the grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Overlapping grade conditions due to multiple independent if statements
misconceptions.description: All letter grade checks are written as separate if statements that only test a lower bound (>= 90, >= 80, >= 70, >= 60, < 60). This means many grades satisfy multiple conditions, causing multiple letter grades to be printed instead of exactly one correct letter.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that checking grade >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60 as separate if statements will automatically correspond to disjoint ranges and produce a single appropriate letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Separate if statements are all evaluated independently. For mutually exclusive grade ranges like A, B, C, D, and F, you must either (1) use an if/else-if/else chain so only the first matching condition runs, or (2) make each if condition explicitly specify a non-overlapping range (e.g., grade >= 80 && grade <= 89).
symptoms: For grade = 95, the program prints A, B, C, and D on separate lines.
For grade = 85, the program prints B, C, and D.
Multiple letter grades can be printed for a single numeric grade instead of exactly one.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how multiple if statements are evaluated and how to create non-overlapping Boolean ranges. The student likely does not recognize that each if is checked even if a previous condition was true, and that simple '>= threshold' checks overlap.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the grade checks to an if/else-if/else chain (e.g., if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ... ) or add upper bounds to make the ranges non-overlapping (e.g., if (grade >= 90 && grade <= 100), else if (grade >= 80 && grade <= 89), etc.).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The conditional structure uses only lower bounds with separate if statements. Given the problem's required disjoint ranges, this pattern necessarily produces overlapping matches, which clearly contradicts the intended behavior.

evidence.note: Each condition is a standalone if with only a lower bound (or a single upper bound for F), so a high grade like 95 satisfies all four upper-grade conditions, leading to multiple letters being printed.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output

misconceptions.description: The program prints only the raw letter (e.g., "A") rather than the labeled output specified in the assignment (e.g., "Letter grade: A").
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that printing just the letter is sufficient to satisfy the output requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The output should match the problem's specified format, including the label. For example, it should print "Letter grade: B" for an 85, not just "B".
symptoms: Output lines are just single letters, such as "A" or "B".
The label "Letter grade:" from the sample run is missing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to the exact output format shown in the sample run, focusing more on the conditional logic than on matching the specified text.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the print statements to include the label, for example: System.out.println("Letter grade: A"); and similarly for B, C, D, and F.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The grading code clearly prints only the letter, and the assignment explicitly shows a labeled output format in the sample run.

evidence.note: Each branch prints only the bare letter without the "Letter grade:" label required by the sample output.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding Input Value
misconceptions.description: The student has hardcoded the analyzed grade value (95.0) instead of reading it dynamically from the user input as required by the problem statement. This often indicates a misunderstanding or negligence regarding dynamic input requirements vs. internal testing/practice.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that defining a fixed value for 'grade' is sufficient to satisfy the requirement of 'reading a numeric grade'.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use the `Scanner` object to read a value provided by the user during runtime to ensure interactivity and correct program functionality.
symptoms: The grade processing logic always uses the same value (95.0)
Missing prompt and `input_scanner.nextDouble()` call for the grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Focusing on the conditional logic and overlooking the requirement to read external data interactively. The student has the necessary `Scanner` object available but does not use it for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the line `double grade = 95.0;` with code that prompts the user and reads the input using the existing `input_scanner` object.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Direct violation of the input requirement, clearly demonstrated by the hardcoded value on line 45.

evidence.note: The grade is hardcoded instead of being read from the user.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Cascading Conditional Logic Failure (Missing else-if)
misconceptions.description: The student uses a series of independent `if` statements instead of `if-else if-else` structure (or explicit range checks) for mutually exclusive grade ranges. This means that if a grade meets the highest condition (e.g., >= 90), it will also sequentially meet all lower conditions (>= 80, >= 70, >= 60), resulting in multiple outputs (e.g., A, B, C, D) for a single grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that an `if` statement checks for an exclusive range boundary (e.g., that if a grade >= 90 prints 'A', the program will automatically stop checking the lower bounds that the grade also satisfies).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Standard sequential `if` statements are all evaluated regardless of previous outcomes. To implement mutually exclusive decision paths based on cascading bounds, one must use `if...else if...else` to prevent the flow of control from entering subsequent lower-bound checks once a higher bound is met.
symptoms: Multiple letter grades printed for high scores (e.g., A, B, C, D for 95).
The logic for 'B' (>= 80) is executed even when 'A' (>= 90) is true.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the control flow provided by independent `if` statements versus mutually exclusive `if...else if` constructs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the subsequent `if` statements to `else if` statements to ensure only one grade is printed.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The misuse of independent `if` statements to handle grade ranges is a classic error for this type of problem, confirming a conceptual misunderstanding of conditional flow control.

evidence.note: A series of independent 'if' statements is used for grade ranges, causing cascading output failures for higher grades.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Independent If Statements Instead of If-Else-If Chains
misconceptions.description: Student uses multiple independent if statements for mutually exclusive grade ranges, causing all matching conditions to execute and produce multiple outputs instead of selecting one letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: Each if statement is completely independent. If a condition is true, its statement executes. Multiple if statements can all execute if their conditions are all true.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For mutually exclusive conditions (like grade ranges), use if-else-if chains or ensure explicit mutual exclusivity with AND conditions. This ensures only one branch executes, preventing multiple outputs for a single input.
symptoms: For grade=95, outputs four letters (A, B, C, D) instead of one
Program prints multiple lines when should print single grade
No logical exclusivity between conditions
misconceptions.root_cause: Misconception about how control flow works in if-else statements; lack of understanding that else-if creates mutual exclusivity; may come from thinking of if statements as independent units rather than part of a decision tree
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the independent if statements with if-else-if chains: if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { ... }. This ensures only one block executes.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly demonstrates this misconception: with grade=95.0, the conditions (grade >= 90), (grade >= 80), (grade >= 70), and (grade >= 60) are all true, and each triggers a separate println. This is unambiguous evidence of not understanding if-else-if exclusivity.

evidence.note: Five independent if statements instead of if-else-if chain. When grade=95.0, all conditions except (grade < 60) are true, so lines 40-43 all execute, printing A, B, C, D on separate lines.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded Grade Value Instead of Reading User Input
misconceptions.description: Student hardcodes the grade as 95.0 instead of using Scanner to read a numeric grade from the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The grade can be set as a constant value in the code (e.g., 'double grade = 95.0;') to test the grade-checking logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading the numeric grade from user input using Scanner.nextInt() or Scanner.nextDouble() after prompting the user. The grade should come from System.in, not be hardcoded.
symptoms: Program does not prompt user to enter a grade
No use of Scanner.nextInt() or Scanner.nextDouble() to read the grade
Grade is fixed at 95.0 regardless of user input
Cannot test with different grade values
misconceptions.root_cause: Student understands Scanner exists (evidenced by its use for distance input) but did not apply it to read the grade. May be an incomplete implementation or misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add code before the grade checking logic to prompt and read the grade from the user: System.out.print('Enter grade: '); double grade = input_scanner.nextDouble();. This should replace the hardcoded line 'double grade = 95.0;'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows 'double grade = 95.0;' with no Scanner call to read the grade. This is unambiguous evidence that the student did not implement input reading for the grade.

evidence.note: Grade is hardcoded to 95.0. There is no System.out.print prompt or Scanner.nextDouble() call to read the grade from the user before this line.
